verses.text: The plans of the heart belong to a person, but the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the partnership between human effort and divine sovereignty. While people can make plans, only God gives the final result and speech. There's a hint of relying on God's wisdom beyond our own understanding (cf. James 1:5), which echoes the need for the faithful to consult God's will in all things.

verses.text: All a person’s ways seem pure in their own eyes, but the Lord weighs the spirits.
verses.comment: Human self-perception can be biased, while God alone knows our true motives. This verse teaches the need for humble self-examination and openness to God's judgment (cf. 1 Cor. 4:4-5).

verses.text: Commit your works to the Lord, and your plans will be established.
verses.comment: When people entrust their actions to God, He gives their efforts lasting value. This calls for trusting God with both one's intentions and deeds, echoing a spiritual discipline of surrender and trust.

verses.text: The Lord has made everything for its purpose, even the wicked for the day of disaster.
verses.comment: God is sovereign over creation, using even wicked people to fulfill His broader purposes. This affirms that nothing is outside God's providential plan, which can be a call to trust in His overarching justice.

verses.text: Everyone who is arrogant in heart is detestable to the Lord; be sure of this, they will not go unpunished.
verses.comment: Pride distances people from God’s favor and ultimately brings consequences. Humility is a core virtue (see Phil. 2:3-8), and it aligns believers with Christ’s meekness.

verses.text: By mercy and truth iniquity is atoned for, and by the fear of the Lord one turns from evil.
verses.comment: Genuine repentance involves both loving-kindness and faithfulness, and true conversion leads to a changed life. This verse hints at sacramental means of dealing with sin, ultimately fulfilled in Christ (see 1 John 1:7,9).

verses.text: When a man's ways please the Lord, even his enemies make peace with him.
verses.comment: God’s favor brings harmony into relationships, sometimes even turning hostility into peace. The spiritual life calls us to focus first on pleasing God.

verses.text: Better is a little with righteousness than great income with injustice.
verses.comment: God values integrity over material prosperity. This wisdom opposes a purely worldly pursuit of wealth and echoes Christ’s teaching against worldly riches (Matt. 6:19-20).

verses.text: In their heart a person plans their course, but the Lord determines their steps.
verses.comment: Human initiative is good, but God’s providence directs the outcome. This is an encouragement toward spiritual trust and acceptance of God’s will in one's vocation or calling.

verses.text: A divine decision is on the lips of the king; his mouth must not betray justice.
verses.comment: Leaders are accountable to God for their judgments. This echoes the concept of authority as coming from God, a principle present from the earliest apostolic communities.

verses.text: Honest weights and scales are the Lord’s; all the weights in the bag are His work.
verses.comment: God is concerned with fairness and justice in business. Calls to integrity have always been a central theme in the biblical moral tradition.

verses.text: It is an abomination for kings to commit wickedness, for a throne is established by righteousness.
verses.comment: Leaders must be just, for their authority loses legitimacy when they are corrupt. Justice is the foundation of stable governance, a principle that applies to both church and society.

verses.text: Righteous lips are the delight of kings, and they love him who speaks what is right.
verses.comment: Speaking the truth is prized in the courts of power. This echoes Christ’s description of Himself as the truth (John 14:6) and invites all to be conformed to Him who is the way, the truth, and the life.

verses.text: A king’s wrath is a messenger of death, but a wise person will appease it.
verses.comment: Wisdom can avert disaster—an echo of how intercessory prayer and prudent counsel can turn aside consequences.

verses.text: In the light of the king’s face there is life, and his favor is like a cloud of the spring rain.
verses.comment: The ‘light of the king’s face’ is symbolic of blessing and grace, reminiscent of God’s own favor. This foreshadows the face of Christ, the King whose blessing brings eternal life.

verses.text: How much better to get wisdom than gold! To get understanding is to be chosen above silver.
verses.comment: Wisdom is to be preferred above wealth, for it brings lasting spiritual treasures—echoes of Christ’s teaching on laying up treasures in heaven.

verses.text: The road of the upright turns away from evil; whoever guards their way preserves their soul.
verses.comment: Living according to God’s statutes guards one's soul. Moral vigilance is an ongoing part of spiritual life.

verses.text: Pride goes before destruction, and a haughty spirit before a fall.
verses.comment: A warning echoed throughout Scripture, pride is the root of many downfalls. This remains a warning against spiritual self-sufficiency and points toward the need for grace.

verses.text: It is better to be lowly in spirit with the humble than to share the spoil with the proud.
verses.comment: Humility is valued above material gain. Christ Himself chose humility (see Phil. 2:5-8), and His followers are called to imitate Him.

verses.text: Whoever pays attention to the word will find good, and blessed is the one who trusts in the Lord.
verses.comment: Blessings result from hearing and trusting God's Word. This also connects to the importance of tradition and instruction handed down through generations.

verses.text: The wise in heart will be called discerning, and the sweetness of speech increases understanding.
verses.comment: True wisdom is shown through gentle words that teach and build up others, a principle essential to the Church’s mission of teaching.

verses.text: Understanding is a fountain of life to those who have it, but folly is the punishment of fools.
verses.comment: Wisdom gives life, echoing Christ, who is Himself Living Water (John 4:14). Folly leads only to death.

verses.text: The heart of the wise makes their speech judicious and adds learning to their lips.
verses.comment: Wise words flow from inner understanding, showing the importance of continual spiritual formation.

verses.text: Gracious words are like honey—sweetness to the soul and health to the body.
verses.comment: Gentle, encouraging speech heals and nurtures. Relating to Christ’s gracious words that brought life and healing.

verses.text: There is a way that seems right to a man, but its end is the way to death.
verses.comment: Human judgment alone is unreliable about final ends. This hints at the need for divine guidance and authoritative teaching.

verses.text: A worker’s appetite works for him; his hunger drives him onward.
verses.comment: Natural desires serve as motivation for diligence. Hard work and discipline are virtues highly regarded in the Christian tradition.

verses.text: A worthless man plots evil, and his speech is like a scorching fire.
verses.comment: Evil intentions are destructive, especially when expressed in words. The New Testament warns about the tongue’s power for harm.

verses.text: A perverse person spreads strife, and a whisperer separates close friends.
verses.comment: Gossip and discord harm community. Unity and peace are central virtues, reflecting Christ’s prayer for oneness among His followers (John 17:21).

verses.text: A violent person entices his neighbor and leads him in a way that is not good.
verses.comment: Evil companionship is a danger; bad influences lead to ruin. The Christian tradition emphasizes the importance of virtuous friendship and avoiding occasions of sin.

verses.text: Whoever winks his eye plans perverse things; he who purses his lips brings evil to pass.
verses.comment: Deceitful gestures reveal evil intentions. Virtue calls for openness and honesty, basic elements of the Christian life.

verses.text: Gray hair is a crown of glory; it is attained by a righteous life.
verses.comment: Aging in holiness is honorable. This underscores the value of elders and the tradition of honoring those advanced in faith and virtue (see 1 Tim. 5:1-2).

verses.text: Whoever is slow to anger is better than the mighty, and whoever controls their spirit is better than one who captures a city.
verses.comment: Self-mastery is held above physical triumph. Growth in virtue proceeds from disciplined spiritual life, as seen in the lives of the saints.

verses.text: The lot is cast into the lap, but every decision is from the Lord.
verses.comment: Even decisions that appear random are under divine sovereignty. This reminds us that God’s providence governs all outcomes, a comfort for life’s uncertainties.
